children.subject:
(in my opinion)
You should try to not worry about how your question sounds, just ask what will help you learn the most. Course staff doesn't judge you, they are there to help all students. Asking questions in itself is a commitment to learning.

Trying out different "kinds" of questions can also be something that you can do because the way you learn is trial and error, you can't make perfect judgment calls without any practice and no mistakes.

Another thing is you can try to reference some things you saw and understood in lecture and narrow down on things you want to hear about.

history.content:
Like Atom said below, course staff are here to help you!! As a former TA, especially in office hours where we can talk to students one-on-one, my goal was always to meet students where they are (whether that's totally lost in lecture or pushing the limits of my own understanding), and go from there. There isn't any amount you are expected to know beforehand. It is very helpful if you explain what you think you do understand, and where you might've gotten stuck.

Examples of things you can ask:

- I understood lecture up to this point, but then I got lost when the professor said this. Could you explain that?

- I was trying to figure out how this thing worked, and this was my thought process, but then something seems to have gone wrong. Help?

- I'm confused about the solution to this problem on discussion/homework. Where did this particular step come from?

- I understand the solution to this problem on discussion/homework, but I couldn't come up with it myself. How should I approach this kind of problem?

- How is this thing we're learning now related to that other thing we learned before?

Of course you can also ask about how to do current homework problems, but honestly that's the least interesting kind of question that you learn the least from... I really encourage you to question your conceptual understanding and bring any clarifications you want to office hours before diving into homework!

Hope that was helpful, and my apologies if any course staff has ever made you feel bad for not knowing enough :(

Hi! I would like to get some advice from everyone in terms of how to approach Office Hours.

I personally always struggle with trying to figure out what kind of questions to bring to Office Hours, how much I can expect to learn from the GSI and how much I am expected to know beforehand. I am always worried that it'll seem to them I didn't watch lectures when in reality I simply don't understand what is going on.

I would really like to take advantage of office hours in this current online setting, but am still very very confused how to make the most of that. So if anyone has advice, I would love to hear it :)
history.subject: How to Ask Questions in OH
